_description: Question definitions, scoring rules, and coaching properties. System file — no client data.

questions.question: What year were you born?
questions.hint: Used for age-specific fitness norms and screening recommendations

questions.question: What is your biological sex?
questions.hint: Used for sex-specific fitness norms and screening recommendations

questions.question: Which preventive care system applies to you?
questions.hint: Determines which screening guidelines we show

questions.question: What is your smoking status?
questions.hint: Some screenings (e.g. lung cancer, aortic aneurysm) depend on smoking history

questions.question: When was your last comprehensive health checkup?
Do you know your key health numbers? (Blood pressure, cholesterol, blood sugar)
What is your waist-to-hip ratio?
questions.hint: Measure waist at navel, hips at widest point. Divide waist by hips. Leave blank if unknown.

sec2.title: Recommended Screenings
sec2.description: Based on your profile, here are the screenings recommended for you. Check the ones you are up to date on.

sec3.title: Blood Markers
sec3.description: Enter your blood test results below. These markers are used to calculate both your Cardiovascular Health Score and your Metabolic Health Score.

questions.question: What is your ApoB level?
questions.hint: Found on advanced lipid panel (mg/dL). Leave blank if not tested.
questions.edgeFloorLabel: ApoB below 30 mg/dL is unusually low — verify with your lab.

questions.question: What is your systolic blood pressure?
questions.hint: The top number, e.g. 120 in 120/80 (mmHg). Leave blank if unknown.
questions.edgeFloorLabel: Systolic BP below 100 mmHg (hypotension) may indicate a health issue.

questions.question: What is your Lp(a) level?
questions.hint: Specialized test, usually in nmol/L. Leave blank if not tested.

questions.question: What is your HDL cholesterol?
questions.hint: Found on standard lipid panel (mg/dL). Leave blank if not tested.
questions.edgeCeilingLabel: HDL above 100 mg/dL may paradoxically increase mortality risk (Madsen et al. 2017) — discuss with your doctor.

questions.question: What are your triglycerides?
questions.hint: Found on standard lipid panel (mg/dL). Leave blank if not tested.
questions.edgeFloorLabel: Triglycerides below 30 mg/dL are very unusual — verify with your lab.

questions.question: What is your fasting insulin level?
questions.hint: Found on metabolic panel (µIU/mL). Leave blank if not tested.
questions.edgeFloorLabel: Fasting insulin below 1 µIU/mL is very unusual — verify with your lab.

questions.question: What is your fasting blood glucose?
questions.hint: Found on basic metabolic panel (mg/dL). Leave blank if not tested.
questions.edgeFloorLabel: Fasting glucose below 55 mg/dL (hypoglycemia) may indicate a health issue.

questions.question: How much do you enjoy your food?
questions.hint: Rate from 1 (not at all) to 10 (always a delight)

questions.question: In which situations does your diet work well?
How satisfied do you feel after eating?
How is your progress towards your goals?

footerLink.description: Use nutrition calculator to calculate optimal protein intake according to your goals.

questions.question: What is your daily protein intake per kg of body weight?
How many meals per day contain the age-related minimum protein per portion?

sec4.title: Nutrition Principles
sec4.description: Check habits you follow 7+ out of 10 days.

questions.question: Which nutrition principles do you follow?

sec1.title: VO2max / Aerobic Capacity
sec1.description: Cardiorespiratory fitness is one of the strongest predictors of longevity. Enter your VO2max from a wearable, the Cooper Test, or a lab test.

questions.question: What is your VO2max?
questions.hint: Enter in ml/kg/min. Check your fitness watch, or use the Cooper Test calculator below.

coaching.preScoreNudge: VO2max is the single strongest predictor of longevity — yet most people have never measured theirs. Without knowing your number, you can't see your biggest lever.
coaching.concreteBenefit: Every MET you gain gives you more energy for daily life and adds measurable longevity protection.
coaching.recoveryNudge: VO2max bounces back quickly — a few weeks of consistent movement will reverse this.

q1_initial.headline: Your VO2max puts you in the bottom quartile — but this is where gains come fastest
q1_initial.detail: People starting here typically gain 1 MET (3.5 ml/kg/min) within 4–6 weeks of regular brisk walking. That means climbing 2–3 flights of stairs without stopping for breath. VO2max is the strongest single predictor of all-cause mortality — and it's highly trainable at any starting point.

q1_improved.headline: You're making real progress — every point of VO2max you gain adds measurable daily capacity
q1_improved.detail: The improvement you've made translates directly to easier movement: less breathlessness on stairs, more energy for daily tasks. Keep this trajectory — research shows the biggest mortality reduction comes from moving out of the bottom 25%.

q1_stable.headline: Your VO2max hasn't changed yet — let's find what unlocks movement for you
q1_stable.detail: Even 10 minutes of brisk walking per day can start shifting VO2max within weeks. The key is consistency, not intensity. Could you add a short walk after one meal each day?

q1_declined.headline: Your VO2max has dipped — this is common and reversible
q1_declined.detail: VO2max fluctuates with illness, stress, and inactivity. A few weeks of regular movement will recover what you've lost. The important thing is restarting, not where you restart from.

q2_initial.headline: You have a solid foundation — the next tier unlocks noticeably easier daily movement
q2_initial.detail: At your current level, daily activities are manageable but may still feel effortful. Improving by 1 MET means brisk walking feels easy, moderate hikes become enjoyable, and you recover faster from physical tasks. This is achievable in 4–8 weeks.

q2_improved.headline: You've crossed into the next tier — can you feel the difference?
q2_improved.detail: Most people at this stage notice stairs getting easier and energy lasting longer through the afternoon. You're moving away from the risk zone — each additional point compounds your protection.

q2_stable.headline: You're holding steady — now is the time to push for the next level
q2_stable.detail: Consistency brought you here. Adding interval efforts — even short bursts of faster walking — is what drives VO2max from fair toward good. Two sessions per week is enough to see change.

q2_declined.headline: Your VO2max has dropped — worth checking what changed
q2_declined.detail: Common causes: reduced activity during a busy period, illness, or poor sleep. VO2max responds quickly to resumed training. Even 2–3 weeks of regular activity should reverse this decline.

q3_initial.headline: You're above average — pushing further puts you in the protective range
q3_initial.detail: At this level, you can hike, cycle, and handle physically demanding days comfortably. Moving into the top quartile is associated with significantly lower all-cause mortality. You're within reach — structured cardio 3× per week can get you there.

q3_improved.headline: Strong progress — you're entering the range where health protection compounds
q3_improved.detail: Your improvement means more than fitness — it's extending your healthspan. At this level, activities like hill hiking, recreational sports, and active travel become easy. The gap to 'excellent' is smaller than what you've already covered.

q3_stable.headline: Good and consistent — the foundation is solid
q3_stable.detail: Maintaining this level already puts you ahead of most people your age. To push higher, consider adding one high-intensity interval session per week — the most time-efficient way to drive VO2max upward.

q3_declined.headline: A small decline from a good base — easy to recover
q3_declined.detail: You have the fitness foundation to bounce back quickly. Resuming your previous routine should restore your level within 2–3 weeks. Fitness memory works in your favor.

q4_initial.headline: Excellent — you're in the top quartile for your age and sex
q4_initial.detail: Your VO2max puts you in a category associated with dramatically lower mortality risk and high functional independence into older age. Hiking with a heavy pack, vigorous sports, and physically demanding work are all well within your capacity.

q4_improved.headline: You've pushed into excellent territory — this is where longevity protection is strongest
q4_improved.detail: Research shows diminishing returns above this level for mortality — but the functional capacity gains continue. You're building a reserve that pays dividends for decades.

q4_stable.headline: Maintaining excellent fitness — this is the goal
q4_stable.detail: Consistency at this level is more valuable than occasional peaks. Your current routine is working. Focus on sustainability and injury prevention to keep this level for years.

q4_declined.headline: A dip from excellent — your base fitness makes recovery fast
q4_declined.detail: At your level, VO2max fluctuations are normal with training cycles, travel, or seasonal changes. Your cardiovascular system retains adaptations well — a focused 2–3 week block will restore your level.

q5_initial.headline: Superior — you're performing at an exceptional level
q5_initial.detail: Your VO2max places you in the top 3% for your age and sex. This level of cardiovascular fitness is associated with the lowest possible mortality risk. You have the aerobic capacity for mountaineering, competitive endurance sports, and sustained high-output activities.

q5_improved.headline: You've reached the highest tier — an extraordinary achievement
q5_improved.detail: Very few people achieve this level. You're maximizing both longevity protection and functional capacity. The focus now is maintaining this through smart, sustainable training.

q5_stable.headline: Maintaining superior fitness — you're in the optimal zone
q5_stable.detail: At this level, the priority shifts from improvement to longevity of the habit. Injury prevention, recovery quality, and training variety keep you here for years rather than months.

q5_declined.headline: A step back from superior — still in excellent range
q5_declined.detail: Even with a decline, you're likely still in the top 10%. The fitness base you've built retains well. Adjust training load or recovery as needed — you know your body at this level.

questions.question: How did you measure your VO2max?
questions.hint: Informational only — does not affect your score

sec2.title: Muscle Strength
sec2.description: Muscle strength predicts functional independence and longevity. Complete one or both tests below.

questions.question: How many consecutive push-ups can you complete?
questions.hint: Men: standard (from toes). Women: modified (from knees). Maintain proper form throughout.

questions.question: How many chair stands can you do in 30 seconds?
questions.hint: Stand fully from a chair and sit back down. Count complete cycles. This test is for ages 60+.

questions.question: How many hours of sleep do you typically get per night?
questions.hint: Average over the past month

options.label: Less than 5 or more than 10 hours

questions.question: How consistent is your sleep schedule?
questions.hint: Same bedtime and wake time each day

questions.question: How would you rate your overall sleep quality?
questions.hint: Over the past month — 1 (terrible) to 10 (excellent)

questions.question: How often do you wake up feeling rested and refreshed?

options.label: Every day or almost every day

questions.question: How often do you have trouble falling or staying asleep?
What is your average wearable sleep score?
questions.hint: 30-day average from your wearable app (0–100). Leave blank if you don't use a sleep tracker.

questions.question: How often do you experience positive emotions such as joy, gratitude, or contentment?
How often do you get fully absorbed in activities you enjoy?
questions.hint: "Flow" — losing track of time while doing something engaging

questions.question: How would you rate the quality of your close relationships?

options.label: Fair — some connections but lacking depth

questions.question: To what extent do you feel your life has a sense of purpose or meaning?

options.label: Strong and clear sense of purpose

questions.question: How often do you feel a sense of accomplishment or progress toward your goals?

options.label: Often — steady but could be more

questions.question: Which best describes the stress you typically experience?
questions.hint: Eustress (challenge stress) energizes you; distress drains you

options.label: Mostly challenge stress — stretched but energized
A healthy mix — some motivating, some draining
Chronic overwhelm affecting health and sleep

questions.question: How quickly do you recover after stressful periods?
Do you regularly practice any stress-management techniques?
questions.hint: e.g. meditation, breathwork, journaling, time in nature, therapy

low.title: Your mindset score needs attention
low.text: Sustained healthy behaviors reduce mortality by 66% — but sticking with them requires the readiness and grit this section measures. Tap to learn what your score means.

belowAvg.title: Your biggest opportunity: {section}
belowAvg.text: You're building awareness — now focus on {section} to unlock the next level. Every improvement here makes your other health habits more sustainable.

aboveAvg.title: Good foundation — keep building
aboveAvg.text: You're above average. Strengthening {section} is your highest-leverage next step — small gains here compound across all your health behaviors.

high.title: Strong mindset — you have the foundation
high.text: Your psychological readiness makes all other health habits sustainable. Tap to see the research behind your advantage.

questions.question: When you think about your long-term health, which of these describe where you are?

options.label: I'm the one who must change it
I believe I can do it

questions.question: How long have you consistently maintained your current health habits?
When you miss a workout or break a health routine, what do you typically do?

options.label: Get back on track the next day

questions.question: When you struggle with a health goal, what do you believe?

options.label: I can learn and improve with effort
I can improve, but it's hard to change habits
Some things improve, but my health is mostly genetic
My health is largely out of my control

questions.question: How do you prioritize preventive health compared to treating problems when they arise?

options.label: I mostly react when issues come up
I only deal with health when I have to

de.name: General Health Check-up (Check-up 35)
de.desc: Blood pressure, lipids, glucose, kidney function, hepatitis B/C

de.name: Skin Cancer Screening
de.desc: Full-body dermatological exam for melanoma and other skin cancers

de.name: Dental Check-up
de.desc: Oral exam, tartar removal, periodontitis screening

de.name: Cervical Cancer Screening
de.desc: Pap test (20–34 annually) or Pap + HPV co-test (35+ every 3 yr)

de.name: Colorectal Cancer Screening
de.desc: Annual stool test (50–54) or colonoscopy (from 50 men / 55 women)
de.freq: Stool test annually / colonoscopy every 10 yr

de.name: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Screening
de.desc: One-time ultrasound to detect aortic aneurysm

de.name: Eye Exam
de.desc: Comprehensive eye and vision exam (glaucoma, macular degeneration)

us.name: Blood Pressure Screening
us.desc: Check for hypertension — the leading modifiable cardiovascular risk factor

us.name: Lipid Panel (Cholesterol)
us.freq: Every 4–6 years (every 3 yr if near threshold)

us.name: Blood Glucose / Diabetes Screening
us.desc: Fasting glucose or HbA1c for prediabetes and diabetes

us.name: Cervical Cancer Screening
us.desc: Pap test every 3 yr (21–29) or HPV test every 5 yr (30–65)
us.freq: Pap every 3 yr / HPV every 5 yr

us.name: Colorectal Cancer Screening
us.desc: Colonoscopy every 10 yr, or stool-based test annually
us.freq: Colonoscopy every 10 yr / stool test annually

us.name: Lung Cancer Screening (LDCT)
us.desc: Low-dose CT for current/former heavy smokers (20+ pack-years)

us.name: Prostate Cancer Screening (PSA)
us.desc: PSA blood test — shared decision with provider

us.name: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Screening
us.desc: One-time ultrasound for men who have ever smoked

us.name: Skin Cancer Check
us.freq: Every 2–3 yr (annual if high risk or 65+)

eu.name: Blood Glucose / Diabetes Screening
eu.freq: Every 3 years (if overweight or risk factors)

eu.name: Cervical Cancer Screening
eu.desc: HPV-based screening, adjusted for vaccination history

eu.name: Colorectal Cancer Screening
eu.freq: Every 1–2 years (stool) or colonoscopy every 10 yr
